    Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
    Article Title: Ethics and Religion in Continental Philosophy
    Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
    Issue: jspecphil.26.2.issue-2
    Date: 4 1, 2012
    Abstract: We at SPEP have never been modern and have made a good living off the critique of modernism and of its binary oppositions. But I think that the business as usual of Continental philosophy will have to be expanded to include a critique of the opposition of the human and the nonhuman, of physisandtechne, and of “Continental philosophy” and “science.” For the truth is that we have been a party to the science wars. That is why I think that the work of Catherine Malabou is exactly the sort of work that SPEP and Continental philosophy generally will have to do in the future. We have yet to admit how deeply inscribed the human is in the nonhuman and the technical. We have yet to appreciate that being-in-the-world is not only historicized, gendered, and incarnate but also both a neural and a galactic event, of both microscopic and macroscopic proportions. Can it be of no interest to “philosophy,” can there be nothing to “wonder” about, that our bodies are literally made of stardust? We have yet to realize how deeply interwoven is the imagination of speculative physics with the wonder of the philosophers. If the best we can do is to protect our turf by saying that science does not think, the sciences will steal our thunder, that is, our wonder, right out from under us. Science does think, and science wonders, because wonder is the piety of thought. That is a matter to which SPEP, and Continental philosophers generally, whether they have taken a theological turn or are running in the opposite direction, should give more thought.36 37
    Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.26.2.0333 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.26.2.0333.xml

    Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
    Article Title: Introduction
    Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
    Issue: jspecphil.28.3.issue-3
    Date: 7 1, 2014
    Author(s): Steinbock Anthony
    Abstract: The section entitled “Psychoanalysis: Between Neuroscience and Phenomenology” consists of two articles that probe the limits of psychoanalysis and its relation to other ways of thinking about consciousness and experience. Elizabeth Rottenberg's article, “Foreign Bodies: Psychoanalysis and Neuroscience,” considers the Oedipal dimensions of psychoanalysis's relationship to neurology. Rottenberg suggests that the desire to correlate the phenomena of psychic life with the structures and functions of the brain can be understood as a wish to return to the primal scene of the separation from neurology that was psychoanalysis's founding moment. Returning to this founding moment whereby Freud broke with the French neurologist Jean-Martin Charcot, Rottenberg argues that fundamental to psychoanalysis is a radical conception of trauma as essentially unlocatable, and this conception leads psychoanalysis to resist correlation with neuroscience. Laura McMahon's article, “Home Invasions: Phenomenological and Psychoanalytic Reflections on Embodiment Relations, Vulnerability, and Breakdown,” puts the psychoanalytic accounts of childhood development offered by Freud and Donald Winnicott into conversation with the phenomenological work of Heidegger and Merleau-Ponty. Drawing on these diverse traditions of thought, framed by an analysis of Ingmar Bergman's 1968 film Shame, McMahon explores the ways in which not only our bodies but also our lived space, as an extension of our embodied engagement with the world, are vulnerable to assault.
    Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.28.3.0213 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.28.3.0213.xml

    Journal Title: The Journal of Speculative Philosophy
    Article Title: Is a Hermeneutic Phenomenology Wide Enough? A Ricoeurian Reply to Janicaud's
    Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
    Issue: jspecphil.28.3.issue-3
    Date: 7 1, 2014
    Author(s): Davidson Scott
    Abstract: A good model for envisioning how a hermeneutic phenomenology would engage Deleuze can be developed by drawing from resources established elsewhere in Ricoeur's thought. What I have in mind, specifically, is his reading of Freud in the book Freud and Philosophy. There Ricoeur reads Freud's work as “a mixed or even ambiguous discourse, which at times states conflicts of force subject to an energetics, at times relations of meaning subject to a hermeneutics.”22 Freud's energetics, on the one hand, offers a naturalistic account of desire in which it is understood in terms of a cathexis—the placement and displacement of energy. And yet, psychoanalysis continually points back to the work of interpretation in which the psychoanalyst is dealing with conscious representations. The coexistence of these two discourses gives rise to an aporia, which Ricoeur formulates in the following way: “What is the status of representation or ideas in relation to the notions of instinct, aim of instinct and affect? How can an interpretation of meaning through meaning be integrated with an economics of cathexis, withdrawal of cathexis, anticathexis?”23 To solve this aporia, Ricoeur goes on to show that these two discourses in Freud's work are not actually opposed. Instead, as he puts it, “the energetics implies a hermeneutics and the hermeneutics discloses an energetics.”24 25
    Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/jspecphil.28.3.0315 journal-article-10.5325_jspecphil.28.3.0315.xml

    Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
    Article Title: Recovering Hyperbole:
    Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
    Issue: philrhet.45.4.issue-4
    Date: 12 1, 2012
    Abstract: Adopting a hyperbolic perspective is also certainly a way to argue as well as a way to examine other “texts” because it is a trope and figure of thought that reveals those moments within discourse when one is attempting to transcend the bounds of reality because the extraordinary nature of a given situation or subject matter requires the use of an excessive prophetic voice or an ardent polemical exaggeration. As Mileur posits, “The work is a hyperbole, the intersection of other hyperboles, and the subject is, insofar as he can be written about at all, another hyperbole” (1990, 86). Rather than circumventing it, understanding hyperbole as the focus of thought and action can create significant moments of inventioas well aselocutiofor the hyperbolist and critic alike. By approaching a particular text, a critical term, and even a piece of criticism itself from a hyperbolic perspective, one might (re)consider and (re)interpret these “texts” as a stretching of discursive limits that leads one toward a re-presentation of the extraordinary—an attempt to communicate the ineffable or transgress the expressible.
    Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/philrhet.45.4.0406 journal-article-10.5325_philrhet.45.4.0406.xml

    Journal Title: Philosophy & Rhetoric
    Article Title: “Reading the Past against the Grain: The Shape of Memory Studies.”
    Publisher: University of Chicago Press
    Issue: philrhet.46.2.issue-2
    Date: 4 1, 1998
    Abstract: This framework also enhances our ability to answer two other questions. First, how is it that human action both imitates the past and mobilizes it as a resource for innovation? I follow Ricoeur and others in working to open what has often been thought of as a closed hermeneutic circle. Although they labored to unpack it, thinkers as formidable as Martin Heidegger and later Hans-Georg Gadamer nevertheless expressed concern that this circle was in fact the philosophical equivalent of a death spiral (Gadamer 1998, 190–92, 265–66, 293–94; Heidegger1996, 142–43). Ricoeur hopefully proposed that the hermeneutic circle be considered “not a vicious but a healthy circle” (1984, 1:3). Ricoeur perceived the many latent possibilities in humanity's abilities to create and deploy news stories about an old past. But his work needs to be infused with a rhetorical sensibility in order to make this a convincing view. I believe that rhetorical scholars would be well served by returning to Ricoeur to explore how the rhetorical interest in judgment and action might contribute to our understanding of this “healthy” spiral.
    Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/philrhet.46.2.0182 journal-article-10.5325_philrhet.46.2.0182.xml

    Journal Title: Shaw
    Article Title: Dilemmas and Delusions
    Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
    Issue: shaw.34.1.issue-1
    Date: 10 1, 2014
    Author(s): Wixson Christopher
    Abstract: One of my favorite anecdotes comes from Bertrand Russell, whose afternoon ride in the country with Shaw one day ended in a terrific collision that permanently disabled his bicycle but left the playwright's two-wheeler relatively unscathed. Forced to take the slow train back home alone, Russell recalled that “at every station[,] Shaw with his bicycle appeared on the platform, put his head in the carriage and jeered.” While the philosopher muses that Shaw probably “regarded the whole incident as proof of the virtues of vegetarianism,” for me, the story is emblematic of how, as we move forward and arrive at each new juncture in intra- and international discussions of matters of health, politics, technology, economics, and humanity, we discover that Shaw is already there, insistently provoking us with just how far Shavian thought can reach.29
    Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/shaw.34.1.0001 journal-article-10.5325_shaw.34.1.0001.xml

    Journal Title: Shaw
    Article Title: Bernard Shaw and Paul Ricoeur
    Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
    Issue: shaw.34.1.issue-1
    Date: 10 1, 2014
    Author(s): Einsohn Howard Ira
    Abstract: In this connection, two additional Ricoeurian points are worth emphasizing. First, Shaw does not present incontestable evidence to warrant his assertion that we exit the womb untarnished. And there is a good reason for this omission. No such corroboration exists, either in speculative thought or actual experience. Shaw knows this, even if he does not explicitly cite Kant on the limits of human knowledge. For this reason, he couches his deepest feelings about the sanctity of creation and the purity of nascence in terms of a “frame of reference” —what we may call faith—without which our lives could easily be an endless nightmare of unrelieved pessimism. Shaw may enlist Paley and the elaborate inner workings of the famous watch to proffer the notion that there is a designer behind all of the intricate design we see in nature, but he is well aware that while argument by analogy is suggestive, it is not necessarily irrefutable.48 After all, given enough time, the counterargument goes, blind chance could have achieved the exact same results many are anxious to attribute to divine intelligence. For Shaw, then, the extrapolated likeness between the maker of a timepiece and the maker of a universe, with respect to complexity, organization, and purpose, does not constitute a rigorous proof. Nevertheless, it does provide him with sufficient grounds for a rational belief in things unseen. Shaw designates his ethereal architect the Life Force and equates it with Will, Spirit, and the mainspring of life, Creative Evolution. On this faith-based view, Shaw defines the Life Force and its ends as the paramount “good” in the ethical sense and conceives every newborn as similarly good because it comes into being already gifted with a subset of the same Will, Spirit, and Creativity that animates the world. From this angle, we can justifiably say that both Ricoeur and Shaw ground their abiding faith and the hope that flows from it in t~
    Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/shaw.34.1.0133 journal-article-10.5325_shaw.34.1.0133.xml

    Journal Title: Utopian Studies
    Article Title: “Time and History in Blake's
    Publisher: Cambridge University Press
    Issue: utopianstudies.22.1.issue-1
    Date: 1 1, 1998
    Abstract: William Blake's poem Jerusalem(1804–20), like all Perennial utopias, achieves a dialectical synthesis of the ideal and the actual through the narrative focalization of a religious experience at the level of character, one that is at once transhistorical and universal. By reading the poem through the lens of the Perennial paradigm, we discover that the temporal aspects ofJerusalemare intimately tied to the religious dimensions of Blake's utopian vision. In addition to giving us a new way to understand the well-documented distinctiveness of Blake's religious message, the Perennial paradigm shows Blake's soteriology inJerusalemto be utopian rather than salvationist (that is to say, individual-religious as opposed to collective-political). Because of the ultimately subjective nature of apprehension of the Divine Vision, Blake's utopian thought is not “clearly a forward-directed anticipatory and visionary concept,” as Magnus Ankarsjö has recently argued (15). Blake does not rally the reader towards some “ensuing peaceful millennium” (15) but rather to find enlightenment in the eternal moment. In light of Blake's suspicion of ratiocination, combined with his deliberate use of narrative focalization of Albion's religious vision, readingJerusalemas a Rational utopia grounded in Judeo-Christian of notions of Apocalypse is to miss Blake's core religious message.
    Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.22.1.0019 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.22.1.0019.xml

    Journal Title: Utopian Studies
    Article Title: The Rhetorical Function of Utopia:
    Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
    Issue: utopianstudies.23.1.issue-1
    Date: 4 1, 2012
    Abstract: An obvious criticism of Burke's idea of rhetorical transcendence is that it is utopian in the unrealistic sense. It seems so abstract in its focus on generalized terminology and images that it may have no possible concrete object. Burke realized this utopian quality reminiscent of the lack of actualized topos in More's utopian “no-place.” As rhetorician James Zappen explains, “These acts of pure persuasion are devoid of partisan advantage-seeking but also devoid of persuasive purpose. As such, they might not even exist.” The important thing to take away from Burke's ramblings, though, is the humanistic sense that the search for perfection is inherent in human nature and that understanding this utopian impulse can only help us to live and to seek happiness in a world of competing power and advantage: “Let us observe, all about us, forever goading us, though it be in fragments, the motive that attains its ultimate identification in the thought, not of the universal holocaust, but of the universal order…. [E]ach kind strives toward the perfection of its kind, and so toward the kind next above it, while the strivings of the entire series head in God as the beloved cynosure and ninecure, the end of all desire.”35 By36 GodBurke means an ultimate ideal transcending all other symbols and fulfilling all desire—the kind of nirvana that would eliminate the need for further utopia-making altogether. This, of course, is not achievable in the course of history, but the mythic experience of it would activate a downward movement in the process, bringing the transcendent ideals back into the pragmatic world of discourse and human affairs. This would be the function of utopia in Burkean terms, and it would result in a habit of mind that would amount to a large-scale educational scheme—dare I say, the education of desires. If the young were informed of the dialectical-rhetorical process of transcendence from the beginning, ~
    Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.23.1.0113 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.23.1.0113.xml

    Journal Title: Utopian Studies
    Article Title: The Meta-Utopian Metatext:
    Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
    Issue: utopianstudies.23.2.issue-2
    Date: 10 1, 2012
    Abstract: To what extent, then, is this ironization—this celebration and cerebration of indeterminacy—consistent with a progressive and dynamic mode of Utopian thought? Or might it indeed be supposed that this inscription of a plurality of perspectives is not only consistent with but essential to a mode of Utopianism as an expression of the manifestation of imagination in a moment at which art and theory converge—insofar as such contradictions allow for the fact that, as Walt Whitman suggested, we are “large” and “contain multitudes” —and inasmuch as (in Karl Popper's words) “irrefutability is not a virtue of theory … but a vice,” in that “every genuine test of a theory is an attempt to falsify it”?105 Could the imaginary testing of theory advanced by art offer the beginning of a grounding of theory in historical materiality? Could art build its Utopian foundations precisely by deconstructing them?106
    Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.23.2.0472 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.23.2.0472.xml

    Journal Title: Utopian Studies
    Article Title: The Problematic of Architecture and Utopia
    Publisher: Pennsylvania State University Press
    Issue: utopianstudies.25.1.issue-1
    Date: 4 1, 2014
    Abstract: If Utopia is as permanent as is desire, its survival does not depend on either Marx or communism. Nonetheless, Utopia may be just what Marx needs now, lending to Marxism a preoccupation with space and the city and dreams that it lacks—a significant enhancement that Harvey in Spaces of Hopeand, earlier, Lefebvre have articulated. More to the point, the much celebrated failure of communism and Marxism—to date—makes Utopia even more relevant now. While Vidler recognizes a correspondence between his own thinking and Jameson's, he believes that Utopia is all but impossible outside of already transformed conditions: an impossible situation that would inevitably negate any value for Utopia, confirming Vidler's proposition “that utopian thought killed the possibility of utopian thought,” because of its hubris, combined with its very impossibility. In this regard, according to Vidler: “Fredric Jameson has proposed that utopian thought whether in prose or design can offer alternatives in a time of lock-down and melt down…. [B]ut for this to happen, architects have to regain their sense of social responsibility, and their political sanity, vote for a world ruled by communitarian and socialist ethics and practices, and not for a world ruled by the myth that the next technological discovery will provide a solution.” 27
    Link: http://www.jstor.org/stable/10.5325/utopianstudies.25.1.0001 journal-article-10.5325_utopianstudies.25.1.0001.xml

    Journal Title: Children Youth and Environments
    Article Title: “Children's Rights and the Imagination of Community in Bangladesh.”
    Publisher: Oxford University Press
    Issue: chilyoutenvi.24.issue-1
    Date: 1 1, 2000
    Abstract: John Wallis Professor of Philosophy, Religion, and Childhood Studies at Rutgers University, Camden. He is author ofEthics in Light of Childhood(Georgetown 2010) andMoral Creativity(Oxford 2005), as well as co-editor ofChildren and Armed Conflict(Palgrave 2011),Marriage, Health, and the Professions(Eerdmans 2002), andPaul Ricoeur and Contemporary Moral Thought(Routledge 2002).
